description:
The Book of Mormon Card Game is an LDS variation on Go Fish. Cards are numbered 1-13, with each number representing a book from the Book of Mormon. (The books of Enos, Jarom, and Omni are combined onto one card.) There are also four suits, Beehives, Buffalo Skulls, Seagulls, and Wagon Wheels. Players ask others for the cards they need to complete the "Books" by asking either for the name of the prophet pictured on the card (for children) or by quoting a scripture on the card (for advanced players).

The rules make note that this deck of cards is appropriate for other standard card games as well.

In this future scenario, you play a hunter trying to bring his/her quota of mutant deer back to the Fish & Game Bureau first.  Players alternate moving their hunter pawn and a random deer pawn.  Cards are drawn depending on certain movement rolls that aid or hinder players.  When moving deer, players can move them toward their hunter, away from other hunters, or to another hunter and roll to attack the hunter and send him/her to the hospital.  Rolls also determine the success of hunters' attacks on deer.

As the maze expands, can you be the first to reach the exit?  Players start in the middle of a maze.  Every turn a player picks a tile and connects it with the tiles already on the table and then moves his/her pawn if desired or possible.  Players attempt to keep their paths open and to block or trap their opponents with strategic placement of the wall tiles.  After the fourth exterior corner tile has been placed, tiles may be replaced as well as placed, and the exit tile is shuffled into the draw pile.  The first player to the exit tile when it appears scores zero points.  Every other player gets points depending on how far their pawn is when the exit is reached by anyone.  The fewest points after a number of rounds is the winner.

The only board game to receive the Top Toy 2008 award from Toy Directory Monthly!  (See link below)

Note:  If playing with only two players, try giving each player two pawns to move.

Received award for Best Vacation Toys 2009 from Dr. Toy.

Each player represents a family trying to marry their three daughters. The daughters have three characteristics: Reputation, beauty, and education, all of which may increase and decrease in value during the course of the game. There are 14 gentlemen in the game, each of them demanding a minimum value in each characteristic. A daughter gets married immediately when she has collected three cards of the same gentleman, and meets the gentleman's standards in each of the three characteristics.

The game ends when a family marries all of their daughters. Points are scored from husbands, action cards, and also from majorities in each characteristic.

The game board depicts different parts of a town, each of them with a different number of available gentlemen cards.

A player's turn consists of:
1. Moving to a different region of the town.
2. Doing a region-specific action, or trying to scheme against another daughter in the same region.
3. Drawing an action card.

Region-specific actions usually mean choosing a gentleman card from those available, but sometimes also cause changes in a daughter's characteristics. Scheming against another daughter means trying to steal a gentleman card from them, by rolling a die. Action cards can be played anytime during a player's turn, and sometimes also as a reaction to cards played by other players.

A table top version of soccer.  Finding a copy intact would be an accomplishment, as not even the the Spears history has a decent picture of it.  One reason children's games are so collectible is that they are rarely found in good condition.

One of Spears' many roll-and-move children's race games.  In this one the players are motorcyclists in a dirt track race.  The pawns are motorcycles.
Special events are triggered when players land on special colored squares.

Players race to be the first back to the starting line.  The first one back wins.

Rules on inside board cover.

From the publisher:

Players move around the game board, decorating Charlie Brown's tree--which really lights up--giving gifts and collecting candy canes. The first player to make it back to the Season's Greetings area lights up the tree and wins!

Includes game board, playing pieces, spinner, game cards and instructions. 2-4 players. Ages 5 and up. Tree includes 2 replaceable button batteries.

There were two editions of this game. One had figurines of the characters; the other had cardboard markers in stands.

"Everybody said you were crazy, but you knew it was only a matter of time... and you were right.

Now they've risen, cold and hungry from the grave. Time to break out the shotguns and crowbars, and start laying the smackdown on some walking dead chumps!

'Zombie Apocalypse' is a miniatures game based on a stripped-down version of the "Action Dice" system. Included in the 22-page rulebook are simple rules for playing out your zombie infestation, 120 Gear Cards, and 70 Zombie Tokens.

Survival is no game, especially on the mean streets of the near future."

Each player has his own mouse. The idea of the game is to use this mouse and try to push as many pieces of cheese as possible to your own hole. Cheesepieces with worms do not score any points in the end.

Spark is an Icelandic (language dependent) trivia game focused on football (soccer). The six categories of questions are about (1) modern Icelandic football, (2) history of Icelandic football, (3) national competition, (4) English football, (5) world clubs and (6) football players.

This game is (by the publisher) intended to be for players 8 to 108 years old. 4150 questions in all, on 1000 cards.

Draumaeyjan (The Dream Island), subtitled A self-help game for an excited nation, is a game where the player decides what kind of industry he wants to build in Iceland, be it heavy industry, knowledge-based industry, tourist industry or agricultural/fishery.

Industries are paid for by resources gained from already built industries (much like in Catan) and monuments can be built after the players have built the pre-required industries. Various cards can be bought or are handed out according to the roll of the dice. These cards can then be used to further ones game or against other players.

Latador is a game designed by Magnús Scheving, based on his play Latibær (which later became a cartoon show called Lazytown.) In Latador the player rolls a die and goes along the track and he has to follow the instructions on each step he lands on, healthy lifestyle and dexterity helps you win the game.

The name Latador is a homage to the Icelandic version of Monopoly which is called Matador. Along the way you can earn money, get few types of cards which can help you or others where you have to move or tell the thruth about your lifestyle.

This game is a variation on the Monopoly theme, with a few differences:

- There are 44 spaces on the board (not 40 as in Monopoly).

- Instead of throwing dice players use sets of 12 tokens with numbers ranged 1-12 and move accordingly to the number shown on the chosen token. Thus Fortuna is much less random than Monopoly.

- There are four "restaurants" and three "railway stations" spaces instead of 4 railway stations in original Monopoly.

- In addition to a possibility of being sent to hospital (an equivalent of prison) players have an option to go to vacation.

Other rules are very similar to the rules of Monopoly.

The board represents Warsaw in 1901.

Salt Lakeopoly is a clone of Monopoly designed by an advertising agency. The real estate squares are all advertisements for Salt Lake City businesses, sports teams, and media. The rules state that the proceeds from the sale of this game are donated to medical research.

Red Square is a very rare Monopoly-style board game with a Soviet theme that was marketed in 1990 (with a copyright of 1988).

Unlike Monopoly, Red Square players compete for privileges -- not properties -- to move up the Soviet social ladder through their status in the Soviet Military and Communist Party. Players acquire wealth by buying and selling on the black market and correctly answering trivia questions about Soviet society and other Russian curiosities.

The winner is the first person to weave their way through the three social classes and make it to Red Square. Players exchange their privileges to move to the next social level -- a concept that is known as nomenklatura in Russian.

CAVEMAN: can your tribe survive? is a survival game where your objective is to become the dominant tribe on Volcano Island. It's a harsh world, where marauding dinosaurs cause chaos, other tribes attack you, and you struggle to help your cave kids survive into adulthood.

Players start from the corner spaces of a hexagonal island, and slowly spread out over the island, looking for resources to help them survive and prosper. The winner is the first player to either expand their population to eight adults, collect all five available resource types, or the player who has made the most progress when the action card deck expires.

This is a trivia game about knowing or  mostly estimating facts from animal  behaviour and facts of all kind of animality. The game includes 100 cards with 100 Questions and answers (on the back side) and four clips in four colours used as player markers.

Players have to estimate facts and behaviours of all kind of animality. There are always 10 different possible answers. Theres a clip for each player to mark their answers on the card. Each spot with an answer can only be taken by one player. When all players made their estimations the card is flipped to the backside with the answer. The player with the correct answer or is closest to it gets the card. If theres a tie the next question/card is worth two cards (the old tied card and the next new card).
The first player with 7 cards is the winner.

The players try to found colonies on planets. They need suitable space vessels to do so. Those space ships will be built from different modules (up to six per ship). It is crucial to get the modules you need to build space crafts as efficient as possible.
You exploit resources and as your empires grows there will be conflict and maybe you extinct all other lifeforms in the universe.

You can add a second game of Vega to have a bigger (modular) map. Instead of playing the standard game you also can play some specific scenarios.

The game consists of
1 Map (9 modular pieces)
12 Objects (planets and asteroids)
4 Sets of colored space ships and 4 Colonies
36 Resources of value 1 to 6
4 Sets of standard moduls (each 9 distinctive ones)
3 Sets of  expansion module (18 different ones)
1 die and rules booklet

Home Page: http://www.bruex.net/vega_01.html

StreetSmart models a rapidly growing city in a developing country.

The players are Capitalists/Politicians/Maffiabosses trying to control as many neighborhoods/slums as possible. Each turn you move one of the city's characters: the Consumer, the Gangster, the Policeman, the Smoker or the Fireman. The characters are moved by simultaneously playing direction cards. Predicting your opponents' moves in order to disrupt their plans is a major part of the game. The game is fast and easy; for a more complex gameplay, there are expansions included in the game:

The Bureaucrat Game adds the Bureaucrat character who creates Addresses and grants Land Titles. The Cholera Game adds an epidemic as well as the Garbageman, Bacterium and Doctor characters. In the Power & Water Game you fight for access to electricity and freshwater for your subjects.

Each expansion can be played in Original Mode, in Chess Mode (no luck factor) or in Political Mode (The players elect a Mayor who then decides who controls which character.)

Defence for Agarthi will be premiered at Essen07
Angelo Porazzi Games Booth 9-30

DEFENCE FOR AGARTHI
Fantasy Wargame Self-produced by Pierluca Zizzi
Illustrations Angelo Porazzi

Follows the description by the author itself:

Game concept
There is a world that from time to time suffers the chaos forces invasions.
There are implacable enemies with supernatural powers dedicated to war and destruction.
There are the watchmen of the cosmic balance who want to defend that world.
Which are the forces YOU will side up with?

Age: 12 o +
Time: 30-90min with 4 or 6 players, 20-30 with 2 players.
Cost: 20 euro

Defence for Agarthi will be present at Essen 07 at Angelo Porazzi Games Booth 9-30

and just after in LuccaGames 07

On http://warangel.it/Aga.html first Lay Out proposed by Angelo Porazzi for the Cover of the Game and some of the many warriors inside the box, illustrated by Angelo Porazzi, graphic by Pierluca Zizzi.

The website of Pierluca Zizzi cannot now be updated with these brand new images: he kindly asked me to publish them, for Essen07 and LuccaGames07 previews.

Biznes po polsku - "Business in Polish" (not "in Poland!") - is a Monopoly based game.

The action takes place in Poland in 1990-s. Socialism is over, capitalism begins. Players try to run their small businesses - hot-dog kiosks, second-hands, money exchange offices, fitness clubs, gasoline stations, etc. There is a lot of jokes and puns connected with the economic system transformation and the politics of the 90-s in this game, particularly on its event cards. The game money notes are well-done one sided copies of present Polish banknotes.

The game mechanics is almost exactly the same as it is in Monopoly, but there are a few noticeable differences. The most important one is that the spaces forming a set are not necessarily close to each other - they can be even placed on opposite sides of a board. The board is not a square but a 11x9 rectangle.

Brings the Supercross experience to life. With movable obstacles, lets you place the doubles, triples and table tops where you want them. With bike modifications and factory rides, you can improve your bike's performance. Be careful of the whoops and don't let your tire drop down inbetween or you'll crash. Family oriented game that is easy to play, which comes with a nicely designed track, cut out bikes and stands, cut out jumps, full throttle, Modification, and obstacle cards, and gear dice for movement. The downfall of the game is the poor design of the jumps.

"HEROES in Mythical Greece" is a greek CCG (Collectible Card Game) that takes place in Ancient Greece. The game is heavily based in the greek mythology trying to be as faithful to it as possible.

The players take control of a famous greek Hero and they play allies, locations, actions and equipment to assist him in his quests. The game can be played in two modes "Duels" and "Quests". In "Duels" two players fight each other, trying each to eliminate the opponent by either reducing his life total or gaining enough fame. In "Quests" players try to advance their Hero, by taking him from his early age and completing quests in order to take fame and have him rise to become a living legend. At the same time their opponents try to stop them by playing monsters that will prevent them from completing their quests. The first one to reach a certain level of fame wins.

Currently, only one set has come out, the first Rhapsody as it is being called, named Genesis. There are plans for more expansions in the following years.

From the publisher: Super Rally is a different game where the board is a trail that changes at each game. Alternate stretches  of forests, cities, fields and deserts with their specific difficulties. As it is a long race night overs and car maintnance must be considered. Everything is present in this game and in order to win, you can't forget anything.
Rather than roll-and-move, players pull cards for their movement.  The goal is to get around the board which shows something like a county fair with the sack race and three-legged race.

Two players compete in trying to collect all the cards in the deck.  To play, all cards are dealt one by one to each player face down in a pile.  The dealer goes first and flips over his top card from his pile onto the center of the table.  The other player flips over his top card onto the played card. If the player places on top of the pile a card with a number (Officers), he captures the pile unless his opponent can recapture them. Recapture is achieved by the player flipping over an Officer card in the amount of turns of the previous displayed numbered card. For example, if the player placed a ‘Cop’ card which is numbered 3, then the opponent would have 3 turns to try and place on top of that card another numbered Officer card.  If he cannot recapture, his opponent gets to take all the cards in the pile.

Stop Thief consists of 32 cards.  There are 20 thief cards and 12 officer cards.  The officer cards include 4 cards depicting each a detective, cop, and police chief.

Game set in the American Wild West.

Object of the game is to win cards having green numbers on them, namely the outlaw or holdup cards.

Game consists of 15 cowboy cards, numbered 1-15, 15 outlaw cards with red numbers 1-15 and green 1-5, 11 holdup cards with green numbers 1-5 and 3 sheriff cards.

The holdup cards form a different stack, top card exposed.
Rest of cards are dealt out.
Players can decide to play either outlaw or cowboy/sheriff each round of play.

After every player has laid out a card, trick is taken by the player with the highest worth in either outlaw or cowboy suit. Sheriff cancels all played cards.
Game plays best with three, if only 2 play, a "dummy" has to be dealt out.
Gameplay also suits for partnership play.

As usual top card quality in graphics and material.

In Hættuspil (or Danger Game) the player takes on the role of a young person and his or her object is to collect the 25 points needed to win. Collecting points is done by buying items according to each person's interests. The points can be lost as well, for example if the player gets a drug card.

The game was designed and published by the founders of CCP to finance the beginning of their EVE Online project.

According to the manual of the 2013 re-release, Danger Game was developed in collaboration with Iceland's Alcoholics Anonymous group to teach children the inherent dangers of drinking and drug use.

The game's original box art features a man, actor Jón Gnarr Kristinsson, dressed as a woman. Years later, Jón Gnarr (as he has legally changed his name to now) would become mayor of Iceland's capitol city Reykjavík. When developer CCP considered re-releasing Danger Game as part of an anniversary box set for EVE Online, it approached the former model and mayor to reprise his role as the damsel on the cover. Gnarr agreed and appears on the reissued game's art.

The Angel Wars strategy board game is simple to learn.  Yet, it has a depth of strategy that is fascinating to players of all levels.  The game features the excellent art and intriguing characters from the amazing animated series, Angel Wars.

The game begins with the game tiles set up in checkerboard design.  You control the 6 guardian angels.  Your opponent controls the 6 demons (or the 6 messenger angels if your opponent prefers not to play the demons).  Players take turns moving, following the rules of movement, until one player has successfully moved all of his/her pieces to the opposite sides of the board.

However, it’s not that simple.  You can only move your piece on a tile of matching color.  Players flip tiles to match their piece.  You must find a way to clear a path for both your blue pieces and your orange pieces while trying to block your opponent’s pieces in the process.

Offering two styles of play, this game is sure to become a favorite among game players of all ages and skill levels.

Roll the diamant die (a transparent d8) to determine the goal-number (= die roll + 4). Then any player is dealt this number of cards from the shuffled deck, that contains the various body parts: feet, legs, torsos, shoulders, and heads in lots of length and combinations.

Your goal is to build a "Langer Lulatsch" (Beanpole) with the right length (the goal-number as number of cards) to get the most points in the round (goal-number +3). Everyone who finishes a correct Lulatsch within the same trun, gets the number of cards of his figure.

The problem is to decide when to add which cards to your figure, as you have only one action per round deciding wether to draw a new card while discarding an old one (either from the drawpile or one of the discardpiles) or "build" your figure. And for example not all feet go with all legs as some have trousers and other have not. Once built you can't change the features and you have to build from bottom to top.

There is another round until the first player gets 50 points.

A monopoly (from Greek monos μÏŒνος (alone or single) + polein πωλεá¿–ν (to sell)) exists when a specific person or enterprise is the only supplier of a particular commodity.

Monopoly is a roll-and-move game where players move around the game board buying or trading properties, developing their properties with houses and hotels. When opponents land on players owned property, the owning player collects rent from the landing player. Owning sets of properties increases the rent paid to the player who owns them, by the player who lands on the square. The ultimate goal is to have the most money and drive opponents into bankruptcy.

A licensed Hasbro Monopoly variant set in Puerto Rico.

The strange name "Casuga Guina" stood for the initials of the surnames of the company designers and publishers: Manuel Calbet, Amando Suriñach, Manuel García, José Luis Guitián and Xavier Navarro. This Spanish company appeared in the mid 80s and published this and another title, Tutankhamon (see entry)

In "Troglodita", each player represents a prehistoric tribe that fights for survival and tries to occupy more caves than the others. In the meanwhile, they have to hunt, fish, confront wild animals, fight another tribes and suffer natural disasters such as earthquakes or epidemies. Obtaining fire is essential to keep food.

The game contents were poorly presented, but it was funny to play and it would have been really good with some extra work on rules and graphic design.

Prophets Card Game is an LDS variation on Go Fish. Cards are numbered 1-13, with each number representing an LDS prophet. (The cards only go through Ezra Taft Benson.) There are also four suits, Beehives, Buffalo Skulls, Seagulls, and Wagon Wheels. Players ask others for the cards they need to complete the "Books" by asking for the name of the prophet pictured on the card.

The rules make note that this deck of cards is appropriate for other standard card games as well.

Another Uno Variation. The Betty Boop Vintage Edition.  Comes in a special collector's tin and stars vintage Betty Boop and company.

WHAT MAKES THIS DIFFERENT FROM TRADITIONAL UNO: On-the-Go card and rule.

Neworld is an economic game where the object is to make as much money as possible, by buying and selling stocks, currency and raw materials. The value of the commodities changes with each turn so the best time for buying and selling varies all the time. The game ends either after a pre-determined time has elapsed or when one player has brought the others to their knees.

The Wild West (TWW) is a game in which each player is a cattle rancher in the American West (mid 19th century), each of whom is trying to extend his “spread” to get access to the resources he needs as well as increasing his worth. TWW can be played by from two to five players.  The game plays somewhat differently based on the number of players involved, but it should take about three hours.

Rustling, Poker Games, Gunfights and the Railroad are all contained in this game of the American West.

Stafaspilið (The Game of Letters) is a lot like Scrabble but without a board. Players get 8 tiles with a letter on each and the goal is to get rid of all the tiles from the hand. Each tile has a value which is used when a word is formed.

Each word that can be read from the new one is counted. For example if a player puts down 'house' he gets points for both 'house' and 'use'. The player who finishes first gets the points from the tiles in the hands of the other players.

In Kvikmyndaspilið (The Movie Game), players form teams (three in each team is best although two player teams can work) and act out scenes from a movie to make their team members guess which movie it is. The opposite team usually chooses the movie and one player of the team tries to act out the scene in less than two minutes. If the team members guess correctly, they can roll the dice and move along the track. Those who are deemed to act exceptionally well get The Oscar statue which gives +1 on a die roll.

From the publisher: "On this superfun lake you'll catch fishes of all sizes. The largeer fishes worth 3 or 5 points each and the smaller ones 1 or 2 points There are also the fishbones that are worthless, they are there just to hinder your fishing. So you'll need a bit of luck to catch the better fishes before the other player. Who get more points at the end is the winner!"

This is a cute little game for the small kids (ages 4 to 8), where two players race to catch the most fish but also the bigger fishes. When all the fishes are caught, players add their points, who got the most wins, simple as that!

This is a simple roll and move game where the players try to get from the starting point to the end, with 90 numbered points on the route, 14 of them with special rules. 13 of those rules have something to do with one of the Icelandic Yule Lads (similar to Santa Claus).

Club 3 was first published as game in the magazine in "WIN" #45, the zine of the "Spielekreis Wien" in Austria. It was published in the Swiss gaming zine "AHA" two months later.

The game is somehow a derivate of Poker - with less cards, less combinations, but more interactions between the players.

The card deck consists of only 24 cards; 4 suits of 6 cards, numbered from 1 to 6.

There are only 3 combinations with a little strange names: 
- Wortklauberei (logomachy): 2 cards with numbers directly adjacent each other
- Redeschwall (flood of words): 2 cards with the same numbers
- Phasendreschen (to rant): 2 cards, 1 showing an "1", the other a "6"

Each round is played with 4 cards per player; there is no possibility to exchange any of them. The first player, who thinks he has a good hand, starts the game by playing 1 card and any number of chips on it. This bet can be attacked by any player. The attacker can choose, if he wants to attack alone or with the help of another player. That means, that the original better can be forced to play against 2 players! An important restriction is, that a maximum of 3 cards can be used on each side, which would form 1 or 2 combinations.

The game ends after a preassigned time and the player with the most chips is the winner.

Godzilla was published in the Swiss gaming zine "AHA" #88/1.

The game is played on a 10x10 board. One player plays with Godzilla, the other one plays with 6 people/tokens from Tokyo. Each of the 6 Tokyo tokens has a different colour and wears an imaginary weapon of the same colour.

Before the game begins, the Tokyo player places 40 houses, 10 monster-immune houses and his 6 tokens on the board. Godzilla waits outside the board.

The Godzilla player is dealt 6 cards showing the 6 colours of the weapons. He is immune against 4 of the 6 weapons and to document which ones, he secretly keeps 4 of the 6 cards.

During a turn, the Tokyo player must move 3 of his tokens by 1 space, the Godzilla player moves Godzilla by 2 spaces. Godzilla can destroy houses, but not Tokyo tokens or monster-immune houses.

The Tokyo player wins, if he can move one of his 2 tokens with a "sharp" weapon on the space where Godzilla is. Godzilla wins, if he can destroy 15 houses before he is killed.

A wargame about the Battle of the Kasserine Pass. The battle was a victory of the Italo-German forces under Erwin Rommel over unexperienced American forces led by Lloyd Fredendall who was relieved after the battle.

The game uses rules of the  B35 (Battles of World War II 1943-1945) system designed for dealing with medium battles of World War II. Counters represent battalions, one hex represents 1000m, one turn represents 8 hours.

A wargame about the final phase of Russian offensive in summer 1944. After the success of operation Bagration and destruction of German Army Group Centre, the Soviets advanced quickly towards the Vistula river and Warsaw. Already exhausted from the earlier fights and 500km advance the Russians encountered strong German forces pulled from the Italian front just when they were about to cross Vistula and capture Warsaw. At the same time the Warsaw Uprising began, complicating the German situation.

The game uses the "Wielkie Bitwy II Wojny 1939-45" or "WB95" (Great Battles of World war II 1939-1945) rules designed to simulate large battles of World War II. Counters represent regiments (Germans) or divisions (Russians), one hex represents 2500m, one turn represents one day.

A wargame about the famous last battle of Napoleon. The goal of the French is to break the Allied line before the Prussian reinforcements arrive and turn the tide.

The game uses a very detailed system designed for dealing with  battles of the Napoleonic Period. Counters represent companies (skirmishers), battalions (regular infantry), regiments (cavalry) and batteries (artillery), one hex represents 120m, one turn represents 20 minutes. At this scale Waterloo, being a large battle, needs 600 counters!

At present rules and all publications about the game are only in Polish language.

Related Microbadges
 Dragon fan

Hastings 1066 is a Tactical level miniatures wargame which was inclued with Practical Wargamer magazine, Jan/Feb 1997 vol 10 no 7. It includes a separate map, rules and counters. Movement and combat are very simple, and are described as a basic outline framework for refighting the battle, with opportunities for improvements and extensions by the players.

A sister game of `Fem myror är fler än fyra elefanter: Lär om bokstäver´, this is a children´s game about numbers. There are seven different ways to play, representing seven difficulty levels.

Players each have their own board. A number of tiles are placed face-down on the table, a la Memory. Players roll the die to see how many tiles (1, 2 or 3) they may turn face-up. Any tiles that match the player´s board are placed on the board.

In the seven variants, players are required to match numbers with numbers (2 - 2, easy), animals with numbers (two lions - 2, slightly more advanced), and so on.

The winner is the first player to fill his/her board.

Themed on a very popular Swedish TV show for kids.

[EN] 11 de Setembre is an introductory wargame with very simple rules, reproducing the siege and fall of the city of Barcelona on September 11th 1714, at the hands of the Spanish-French Bourbon army. The fall of Barcelona effectively ended the War of the Spanish Succession.

It contains one 50x70 cm map, a rulebook and 88 counters.


[CA] 11 de Setembre és un wargame introductori amb regles molt simples i que reprodueix el setge i caiguda de Barcelona l'11 de setembre de 1714 a mans de l'exèrcit borbònic francoespanyol. La caiguda de Barcelona posà fi a la Guerra de Successió Espanyola.

El joc conté un mapa de 50x70 cm, un llibret de regles i 88 fitxes.


[ES] 11 de Setembre es un wargame introductorio con reglas muy simples y que reproduce el asedio y caída de Barcelona el 11 de setiembre de 1714 a manos del ejército borbónico franco-español. La caída de Barcelona puso fin a la Guerra de Sucesión Española.

El juego contiene un mapa de 50x70 cm, un libro de reglas y 88 fichas.

Teams compete to guess closest to the year of a historic event, which is read out from a Question Card.  Winning teams collect tokens and roll the dice to move around the board in a race to the Center.

The game includes a board, eight different characters to represent the teams playing, a sandglass timer, two dice, a scoresheet, six pencils, a novel magnetic category selection unit, question/answer cards, timecards, rules, and a mini-reference sheet.

The game is played in rounds, the first of which is similar to a round of trivial pursuit.  The second round introduces timecards, which tweaks gameplay by giving teams various powers, such as stealing points.  The game sequence also changes to shake things up a bit.

Very much like an exciting Trivial Pursuit, adding various new mechanics.

Released at Spiel 2007.

From the back of the box:

"Since September 27th, 2004, the Dominican Republic has a new criminal procedural law, based in an accusatory system, which replaces the one from 1844 that was  inspired in the old French code based in an inquisitive model.

In order to announce the new legal frame, the Escuela Nacional de la Judicatura presents this process in a ludic educational form to the justice servers, the Policía Nacional and to the citizens in general."
